Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
In the Sanitation Supplements of the Tropical Disea-
ses Bulletin dated March 30, 1922, there is reference to a
French article dealing with yellow fever, which you may wish to
look up. I quote below all that is given in the Sanitation Sup-
plements:

MATHIEU (L). Une page d'histoire sanitaire maritime: defense
contre la fievre jaune au debut du XlXe siecle.- Arch. Med. et
Pharm. Nav. 1921. Nov.-Dec. Vol. 111. No. 6. pp. 477-494.

The writer gives a very interesting account of outbreaks of
yellow fever at the end of the 18th century in Gibralter, Brest
and Marseilles. The disease was brought from San Domingo
originally when the whole of that part of the world was suffer-
ing from a terrible epidemic. The report is of value to anyone
dealing with the early history of yellow fever in Europe and
the methods adopted to prevent its spread.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Florence M. Read Doctor Henry R. Carter
Assistant Surgeon General
U. S. Public Health Service
2121 California Street, N.W.
Washington, D.C.
